title: Percy Waram
text:
Percy Thomas Carne Waram ( ; 28 October 1880 – 5 October 1961) was a British-born stage and film actor who spent much of his career in the United States. His career lasted 55 years on the American stage, and he had memorable roles in "The Shanghai Gesture", "<a href="Elizabeth%20the%20Queen%20%28play%29">Elizabeth the Queen</a>", "<a href="Mary%20of%20Scotland%20%28play%29">Mary of Scotland</a>", "Pride and Prejudice", and "Anne of the Thousand Days". He starred in the Chicago production of "<a href="Life%20With%20Father">Life With Father</a>" for three years, setting box office and attendance records, after which he took the production on the road for another 38 weeks. He starred in the Broadway production of "The Late George Apley" for a year, and then spent another 80 weeks with the show's national tour.
Waram originated the role of Horace Vandergelder in "The Merchant of Yonkers", and appeared in an influential if not successful modern dress version of "<a href="Hamlet">Hamlet</a>".
Waram made only a few films, and had no starring roles, but is best remembered now for his role as General Haynesworth in the film "<a href="A%20Face%20in%20the%20Crowd%20%28film%29">A Face in the Crowd</a>".
Early life.
Percy Thomas Carne Waram was born 28 October 1880 in <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a> in the United Kingdom to Joseph Carne Waram and his wife, Margaret Frances ( Powrie). His father served in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a>, and his mother's family was <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a>. He was a descendant of <a href="Mary%20Saunderson">Mary Saunderson Betterton</a> (1637–1712), the famed Elizabethan era actress. His great-grandmother was <a href="Julia%20Glover">Julia Betterton Glover</a> (1779–1850), the great comic actress of the early 1800s and the first woman to perform in "<a href="Hamlet">Hamlet</a>". His grandmother and mother were also actresses.
As a child, Waram wanted to join the army like his father had. While on holiday when he was 15 years old, he visited his older sister, who was appearing in the play "<a href="East%20Lynne">East Lynne</a>". A member of the cast fell ill, and Waram was cast as a butler in the play. He was immediately recast in the double role of an English nurse (in blonde wig) and French nurse (in black wig). It was his stage debut.
His family's difficult financial condition led him to go to work as an actor. He took a position with the same traveling company in which his sister was an actress, but quit shortly thereafter to join <a href="Ben%20Greet">Sir Ben Greet</a> <a href="Repertory%20theatre">repertory company</a>. He made his London theatrical debut in 1899. Waram came with the Greet troupe when it traveled to the United States in 1902. He made his American stage debut in the play "<a href="Everyman%20%281901%20play%29">Everyman</a>" at the Maryland Theatre in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a>.
After two years in the United States, Waram returned to the U.K. in 1905 to form his own touring troupe. The company largely performed in rural areas, often appearing in "tough mining towns". While performing in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>, an audience member threw a mug of beer at his head, knocking him senseless. Waram decided to rejoin the Ben Greet company after the incident, and traveled with them to the U.S. again. He traveled back and forth between the United Kingdom and United States, appearing in plays on both side of the Atlantic Ocean. He permanently relocated to the U.S. in 1908.
Stage work.
Early years.
The Greet troupe specialized in presenting plays by <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>, and Waram appeared in "<a href="As%20You%20Like%20It">As You Like It</a>", "<a href="The%20Merchant%20of%20Venice">The Merchant of Venice</a>", "<a href="Macbeth">Macbeth</a>", "<a href="Julius%20Caesar%20%28play%29">Julius Caesar</a>", "<a href="Much%20Ado%20About%20Nothing">Much Ado About Nothing</a>", "<a href="A%20Midsummer%20Night%27s%20Dream">A Midsummer Night's Dream</a>", "Hamlet", and "<a href="The%20Taming%20of%20the%20Shrew">The Taming of the Shrew</a>". The Greet players occasionally did other plays, and Waram appeared in "<a href="She%20Stoops%20to%20Conquer">She Stoops to Conquer</a>" in 1908.
Waram sometimes worked for other companies as well. He appeared in the Violet Allen Company's production of "<a href="Twelfth%20Night">Twelfth Night</a>" an American tour in 1903, the Frances Delaval Company's production of "Her Lost Self" at the <a href="St.%20James%27%20Theatre">St. James' Theatre</a> in London in 1906, and performed for the <a href="William%20Faversham">William Faversham</a> Company in 1909.
In 1910, Waram formed a very small troupe under the name "Percy Waram & Co.", and toured the <a href="Keith-Albee-Orpheum">Keith-Albee-Orpheum</a> and <a href="F.%20F.%20Proctor">Proctor</a> theater circuits in <a href="vaudeville">vaudeville</a> in the sketch "The Boatswain's Mate" ( "The Bos'n's Mate"). <a href="W.%20W.%20Jacobs">W. W. Jacobs</a> and Herbert N. Sargent wrote the sketch specifically for Waram, adapting a short story of the same name by Jacobs. The sketch made its debut at the Montauk Theatre in <a href="Passaic%2C%20New%20Jersey">Passaic, New Jersey</a>, and Waram & Co. performed it until October 1915. Vaudeville proved highly lucrative for him.
Broadway debut and other early stage work.
Waram most likely made his Broadway debut in the 1909 production of "The Barber of New Orleans" at <a href="Daly%27s%20Theatre">Daly's Theatre</a>. The following year he appeared in <a href="Arthur%20Conan%20Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a> play "<a href="The%20Tragedy%20of%20the%20Korosko">The Fires of Fate</a>" at the <a href="Liberty%20Theatre">Liberty Theatre</a> on Broadway.
After his three years in vaudeville ended, Waram returned to the stage as <a href="Captain%20Alexander%20Smollett">Captain Smollett</a> in "<a href="Treasure%20Island">Treasure Island</a>". The play premiered in June 1916 at the Colonial Theatre in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>. In October, the production moved to the <a href="Charles%20Hopkins%20Theatre">Punch and Judy Theatre</a> on Broadway, The play was Waram's first hit, running for 331 performances.
Waram returned to Broadway in the Mark Swan play "Somebody's Luggage" at the <a href="48th%20Street%20Theatre">48th Street Theatre</a> in August 1916. This was followed by the role of the Gardener in the Charles Frohman Company's production of <a href="J.%20M.%20Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a> play "Barbara's Wedding". The play had its world premiere in <a href="Buffalo%2C%20New%20York">Buffalo, New York</a>.
His second hit play was <a href="Jane%20Cowl">Jane Cowl</a> and <a href="Jane%20Murfin">Jane Murfin</a> "Lilac Time", and his first important role. He played Captain Paget in the national touring company, which had a long run in Chicago in early 1918. He joined Walter Faversham's production of "<a href="Lord%20and%20Lady%20Algy%20%28play%29">Lord and Lady Algy</a>", which premiered at the <a href="Shubert%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Shubert Theatre</a> on Broadway in December 1918, and stayed with the production during its 1919 national tour. He played the role of Lord Andrew Gordon in <a href="Guy%20Bolton">Guy Bolton</a> and <a href="George%20Middleton%20%28playwright%29">George Middleton</a> play "Adam and Eva" during its national tour, which began in the summer of 1920 and did not end until March 1921. He followed by playing the role of George Herbert in Norman Trevor's Little Theater Group production of "The Married Woman" at Broadway's <a href="Princess%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%20City%2C%201913%E2%80%931955%29">Princess Theatre</a> in December 1921.
Waram appeared in a number of Broadway plays over the next five years: As Phillip Blanchard in <a href="Eden%20Philpotts">Eden Philpotts</a>' "The Shadow" at the <a href="Klaw%20Theatre">Klaw Theatre</a> in April 1922, as the Elder Brother in "The Lucky One" at the <a href="Garrick%20Theatre">Garrick Theatre</a> in November 1922, as Jacques in "The Tidings Brought to Mary" at the Garrick Theatre in December 1922, as Domin in "<a href="R.U.R.">R.U.R.</a>" at the Shubert Theatre in April 1923, as Winthrop Field in "A Love Scandal" at the <a href="Ambassador%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Ambassador Theatre</a> in November 1923, as Beaucaire in "Monsieur Beaucaire" at the <a href="Old%20National%20Centre">Murat Theatre</a> in <a href="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a> in May 1924, as Maitland White in <a href="Philip%20Barry">Philip Barry</a> "You and I" at the Murat Theatre in May 1924, as Hugh Chadwell in <a href="Walter%20Archer%20Frost">Walter Archer Frost</a> "Cape Smoke" at the <a href="Al%20Hirschfeld%20Theatre">Martin Beck Theatre</a> in February 1925, as Horatio in a modern dress version of "Hamlet" at the <a href="Booth%20Theatre">Booth Theatre</a> in November 1925, and as Citizen Hogan in "Hangman's House" at the <a href="Eugene%20O%27Neill%20Theatre">Forrest Theatre</a> in December 1926. Waram later considered his role in the modern dress "Hamlet" to be one of the most important in his career.
"The Shanghai Gesture" and stardom.
After a run of nearly a year on Broadway, <a href="John%20Colton%20%28screenwriter%29">John Colton</a> hit play "The Shanghai Gesture" began a national tour, which began in Chicago in March 1927. Waram played Sir William Charteris, taking over from <a href="McKay%20Morris">McKay Morris</a> (who originated the role on Broadway). The play altered his career, turning him into a major star on the stage. After a four month run in Chicago, the play moved to <a href="Salt%20Lake%20City">Salt Lake City</a> in May 1927, and <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> in June. After a four month run in California, the play moved to <a href="Kansas%20City%2C%20Missouri">Kansas City</a>, where it broke box office records for attendance. The play then toured <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>, <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a>, <a href="Montr%C3%A9al">Montréal</a>, <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, and <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, before returning to Broadway's Majestic Theatre on January 30, 1928 for a final, limited run.
Waram worked steadily through the early years of the Great Depression after the success of "The Shanghai Gesture". Taking almost no time off, he appeared as Bill Walker in the October 1928 production of "<a href="Major%20Barbara">Major Barbara</a>" at the <a href="August%20Wilson%20Theatre">Guild Theatre</a>, and the role of the Servant in "Camel Through the Needle's Eye" at the Guild Theatre in April 1929. He left "Camel" after just a week in the role to join the national touring company of "Major Barbara". The role helped cement his reputation as a reliable actor, and brought him to the attention of producers nationwide. After spending the summer on tour, he took the role of Col. Pickering in the regional touring company of "<a href="Pygmalion%20%28play%29">Pygmalion</a>". The play premiered in September 1929 at the Wilson Theatre in Detroit for tryouts before moving to Indianapolis, <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>, Chicago, and Pittsburgh.
In October 1930, Waram originated the role of Sir Walter Raleigh in <a href="Maxwell%20Anderson">Maxwell Anderson</a> new play, "<a href="Elizabeth%20the%20Queen%20%28play%29">Elizabeth the Queen</a>". The play debuted at Ford's Theatre in Baltimore and then played regionally before making its Broadway premiere at the Guild Theatre in November 1930. Waram toured nationally in the role until June 1931.
After taking a year off, Waram took the role of Comte Dubarry in the new <a href="operetta">operetta</a> "The Dubarry", which had its world premiere at <a href="George%20M.%20Cohan%27s%20Theatre">George M. Cohan's Theatre</a> in November 1932. The operetta was not successful, and in April 1933 Waram originated the role of Howard Bartlett in <a href="Somerset%20Maugham">Somerset Maugham</a> new play, "<a href="For%20Services%20Rendered">For Services Rendered</a>". After a tryout in <a href="Oakland%2C%20California">Oakland, California</a>, the first week of April, the play moved to the Booth Theatre on Broadway. The play closed quickly, and was critically panned. Waram's performance was considered the only outstanding aspect of the production. With work on the stage scarce due to the Great Depression, Waram joined the <a href="summer%20stock">summer stock</a> repertory company at the Casino Theatre in <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a>. He appeared in at least one play, the drawing room comedy "<a href="Aren%27t%20We%20All%3F">Aren't We All?</a>" In October 1933, he appeared as Don Salluste de Bazan in an English-language adaptation of <a href="Victor%20Hugo">Victor Hugo</a> "<a href="Ruy%20Blas">Ruy Blas</a>". After a brief run at the Majestic Theatre, the play moved to Baltimore, where it closed after a week. Waram was not out of work long: When <a href="Stanley%20Ridges">Stanley Ridges</a> left the role of Lord Morton (which he had originated) in "<a href="Mary%20of%20Scotland%20%28play%29">Mary of Scotland</a>" at the <a href="Neil%20Simon%20Theatre">Alvin Theatre</a>, Waram took over the role.
After "Mary of Scotland" closed in May 1934, Waram accepted the role of Uncle Robert in "Picnic", a new comedy by Gretchen Damrosch staged at the <a href="Nederlander%20Theatre">National Theatre</a>. The play quickly closed, and Waram returned to the Casino Theatre's summer stock company, where he appeared in "<a href="A%20Bill%20of%20Divorcement%20%28play%29">A Bill of Divorcement</a>" and <a href="Benn%20Levy">Benn Levy</a> "Art and Mrs. Bottle". Although Waram had no contract at the start of the 1934-1935 theater season, he appeared as Henry Pryor in the drama "Living Dangerously" at the <a href="Morosco%20Theatre">Morosco Theatre</a> in January 1935.
Film and stage work after 1935.
First film roles and "Pride and Prejudice".
Waram was cast in his first film in March 1935. The role, a small one which barely made the final cut, was for "<a href="Mutiny%20on%20the%20Bounty%20%281935%20film%29">Mutiny on the Bounty</a>".
After completing work in Hollywood, Waram returned to Broadway in the role of Mr. Bennett in <a href="Helen%20Jerome">Helen Jerome</a> stage adaptation of <a href="Jane%20Austen">Jane Austen</a> "<a href="Pride%20and%20Prejudice">Pride and Prejudice</a>". The play debuted at the <a href="Nederlander%20Theatre">National Theatre</a> in October 1935, and was a major hit. It ran for 219 performances (with only short interruptions for cast vacations) until May 1936.
A series of much less successful plays followed over the next two years. These included the role Sir Hudson Lowe in the American premiere of "<a href="St%20Helena%20%28play%29">St Helena</a>" in October 1936 at the <a href="Lyceum%20Theatre%20%28Broadway%29">Lyceum Theatre</a>, Mr. Pinchwife in "<a href="The%20Country%20Wife">The Country Wife</a>" in December 1936 at <a href="Stephen%20Sondheim%20Theatre">Henry Miller's Theatre</a>, and Malvolio in "Twelfth Night" at the Mohawk Drama Festival in <a href="Schenectady%2C%20New%20York">Schenectady, New York</a>, in July 1937. He joined the repertory company at the County Theatre in <a href="Suffern%2C%20New%20York">Suffern, New York</a>, in the summer of 1937, appearing in "A Bill of Divorcement" and "Pride and Prejudice". After nearly a year's break, Waram returned to the stage in "Ruy Blas" at a drama festival in <a href="Central%20City%2C%20Colorado">Central City, Colorado</a>, in May 1938.
Three and a half years after "Mutiny on the Bounty", Waram signed to do a second film. He played the role of slumlord business manager Arthur Mather in the social drama "<a href="...One%20Third%20of%20a%20Nation...">...One Third of a Nation...</a>
"The Merchant of Yonkers" and "Life With Father".
In December 1938, Waram originated the role of Horace Vandergelder in <a href="Thornton%20Wilder">Thornton Wilder</a> new play, "<a href="The%20Merchant%20of%20Yonkers">The Merchant of Yonkers</a>". After a brief tryout in Boston, the play moved to the Guild Theatre on Broadway. Actress <a href="Jane%20Cowl">Jane Cowl</a> (who played the role of Dolly Levi) intensely disliked director <a href="Max%20Reinhardt">Max Reinhardt</a>, and Reinhardt retaliated by isolating Cowl physically on stage. The play was considered a disappointment, and ran for only 28 performances.
After another year away from the theater, Waram took the role of "Father" Clarence Day Sr. in a Chicago production of the hit Broadway play "<a href="Life%20With%20Father">Life With Father</a>". After a tryout at the Maryland Theatre in Baltimore, it opened at the <a href="Merle%20Reskin%20Theatre">Blackstone Theatre</a> in Chicago on February 19, 1940. Waram was the first individual to take over the role of Father from the play's co-author <a href="Howard%20Lindsay">Howard Lindsay</a>, who originated the role on Broadway. Waram was widely praised for his interpretation. The play ran for a record 66 weeks in Chicago, with attendance of more than 590,000 patrons and a box office gross of $850,000 ($ in dollars). The play called for Father to stamp a foot on the floor, calling for the cook to come upstairs. Waram stomped so ferociously that he broke his foot, and had to switch feet for the scene. He tried banging on a plate with silverware, but the prop plates broke too easily. He then tried whistling, but was not very good at it. He returned to stomping. When he came down with <a href="gout">gout</a>, he began using a cane to bang on the floor. <a href="Lillian%20Gish">Lillian Gish</a> played opposite Waram as "Mother" Lavinia Day. Waram spent three years in the role.
After a two-month break, a touring company of "Life With Father" began, with <a href="Margalo%20Gillmore">Margalo Gillmore</a> in the role of "Mother". The tour ran until July 1942, and resumed again in October 1942 with <a href="June%20Walker">June Walker</a> as "Mother". After another 38 and a half weeks on the road and net profits of $559,000 ($ in dollars), the tour finally came to an end.
Just as the tour of "Life With Father" came to an end, Waram was cast as Inspector Prentice in Paramount Pictures' <a href="film%20noir">noir</a> <a href="crime%20film">crime film</a>, "<a href="Ministry%20of%20Fear">Ministry of Fear</a>".
"The Late George Apley" and "Anne of the Thousand Days".
After a year away from the stage, Waram returned to acting in the role of Roger Newcombe in an adaptation of the novel "<a href="The%20Late%20George%20Apley">The Late George Apley</a>". Waram originated the role, with <a href="Leo%20G.%20Carroll">Leo G. Carroll</a> in the leading role of George Apley. After a tryout at the Wilmington Playhouse in <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Delaware">Wilmington, Delaware</a>, in October 1944 and the Plymouth Theatre in Boston in November, it made its Broadway debut at the Lyceum Theatre. With only brief interruptions to rest the cast, the play ran until November 1945 on Broadway before embarking on an 80-week national tour.
Just five months after finishing the "Apley" tour, Waram originated the role of Marcus Hubbard in <a href="Lillian%20Hellman">Lillian Hellman</a> play "<a href="Another%20Part%20of%20the%20Forest">Another Part of the Forest</a>". The play premiered in Wilmington before additional tryouts in Baltimore and Detroit. It premiered on Broadway at the Fulton Theatre in November 1946, where it ran for 182 performances. Waram left the show in September 1947.
In June 1946, during the national tour of "The Late George Apley", Waram was cast as Roger Newcombe in the <a href="The%20Late%20George%20Apley%20%28film%29">film version</a>. Filming commenced in September 1947, and did not end until December. Waram only member of the stage production cast in film.
In November 1948, a year after filming "The Late George Apley", Waram originated the role of Cardinal Wolsey in the new <a href="Maxwell%20Anderson">Maxwell Anderson</a> play "<a href="Anne%20of%20the%20Thousand%20Days%20%28play%29">Anne of the Thousand Days</a>". The play premiered at the <a href="Forrest%20Theatre">Forrest Theatre</a> in Philadelphia and moved to Broadway's Shubert Theatre in early December. Waram stayed with the production until early June 1949.
Final years.
Last roles.
Waram was cast in 1949 as senior law partner John Benley, father of <a href="Elizabeth%20Taylor">Elizabeth Taylor</a> Mary Benley, in <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> 1950 comedy "<a href="The%20Big%20Hangover">The Big Hangover</a>".
Now 70 years old, Waram did not work in 1950 or 1951. He returned to Broadway in October 1952 in the dual role of the Station Master and God in <a href="Ugo%20Betti">Ugo Betti</a> play "The Gambler" (adapted by <a href="Alfred%20Drake">Alfred Drake</a>). The play premiered at the Lyceum Theatre, and closed after a short run. Waram returned to acting in October 1954, originating the role of Lucas Edgerton, a wealthy industrialist who goes on an art buying spree, in "Reclining Figure".
Waram's final hit stage role was that of the no-nonsense Judge in <a href="Enid%20Bagnold">Enid Bagnold</a> new play "<a href="The%20Chalk%20Garden">The Chalk Garden</a>". The play had its world premiere at the Shubert Theater in Hartford, Connecticut, before moving to the <a href="Wilbur%20Theatre">Wilbur Theatre</a> in Boston. It made its Broadway debut at the <a href="Ethel%20Barrymore%20Theatre">Ethel Barrymore Theatre</a> in late October 1955, running for 182 performances.
In September 1956, Waram was cast in his final film role, that of General Haynesworth, chief executive officer of a vitamin company, in the film "<a href="A%20Face%20in%20the%20Crowd%20%28film%29">A Face in the Crowd</a>".
Waram appeared in his final stage role in October 1957. He played veteran police inspector Desiré Merlin in <a href="Michael%20Blankfort">Michael Blankfort</a> and Dorothy Stiles Blankfort's new play "Monique". The work premiered at The Playhouse in Wilmington before moving to Broadway's <a href="John%20Golden%20Theatre">John Golden Theatre</a> two weeks later. The play closed after 63 performances.
Death.
Waram's wife, Lucia, died in March 1961.
In September 1961, Waram traveled to <a href="Huntington%2C%20New%20York">Huntington, New York</a>, to be close to his daughter, who was ill. He entered the hospital himself on September 24, and died on October 5, 1961, at Huntington Hospital of an undisclosed illness. His funeral was held at Calvary Episcopal Church in <a href="Stonington%2C%20Connecticut">Stonington, Connecticut</a>, and he was buried at <a href="Stonington%20Cemetery">Stonington Cemetery</a>.
Personal life.
Percy Waram married Lucia Cole, an American stage actress, on February 11, 1909. They met when she appeared alongside Waram in "Everyman" in 1902, and she later joined the Ben Greet company. The couple made their home in Stonington, and maintained a second home on the <a href="Cornwall">Cornish</a> coast. The couple had two children: Frances Cole Waram (1911-1994), who married John H. Trowbridge in 1937, and Julian Thomas Cole Waram (1913-1982), for years a member of the <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard">United States Coast Guard</a>. Waram's children were educated at a private school in <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.
Waram once voiced a fondness for quiet roles, and later said he preferred bloody mystery-thrillers.
<a href="Boating">Boating</a> and <a href="golf">golf</a>ing were Waram's favorite pastimes, and he often smoked <a href="cigar">cigar</a>s. He was a member and strong supporter of the <a href="Actors%27%20Equity%20Association">Actors' Equity Association</a> (the American stage performer's union).
Waram went mostly <a href="hair%20loss">bald</a> early in life. He had mid frontal baldness, and wore a <a href="toup%C3%A9e">toupée</a> on stage in most of his roles. While starring in the play "Lilac Time", his toupée caught on a piece of stage scenery. The near-disaster led him to grow out a mustache out of a fear that a fake mustache would fall off during a performance.
